awd_titl_txt: FRG: Collaborative Research: von Neumann Algebras Associated to Groups Acting on Hyperbolic Spaces
awd_abstract_narration:
The study of von Neumann algebras was initiated in the 1930s and 1940s by F. Murray and J. von Neumann as a mathematical tool to understand particle physics. Subsequently, it became an independent discipline that has stimulated the development of powerful mathematical theories and bringing valuable insight to physics (statistical mechanics), biology (DNA structure), and engineering (cell phone network design). Von Neumann algebras are highly interdisciplinary in nature as they arise canonically from simpler mathematical structures, such as symmetries and actions, often present in many areas of mathematics. Over time their study remained closely connected with various topics in dynamical systems, measured group theory, and more recently geometric group theory. This project investigates several major open problems inspired by the rich interaction between operator algebras and the aforementioned fields.

This research project explores new horizons in the classification of group von Neumann algebras. The first objective of the project is to advance Connes' rigidity conjecture, a major wide-open problem predicting that ICC property (T) groups are completely recognizable from their von Neumann algebras (W*-superrigid). The PIs proposed several natural constructions of W*-superrigid property (T) groups based on new developments in geometric group theory and deformation/rigidity theory. The second objective of the project revolves around the study of prime II1 factors. The main focus is to understand the relationship between various manifestations of negative curvature in group theory and primeness aspects of the corresponding group factor. The results arising from this project are expected to reveal significant cross-pollination between, geometric group theory, ergodic theory, random walks, C*-algebras, and von Neumann algebras. The PIs intend to organize a series of workshops aimed at stimulating collaboration between experts in these fields. To promote the career development of graduate students the proposal also involves a student exchange program between the participating institutions aimed at exposing students to different expertise and research environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Von Neumann algebras are certain collections of infinite matrices (bounded Hilbert space operators) that were originally introduced in the 1930s as a tool to understand quantum mechanics. Soon after their introduction, it was realized that von Neumann algebras arise naturally from groups of symmetries. There has been a lot of interest over the years in studying, and ultimately classifying, von Neumann algebras associated to groups.

The main goal of the intellectual merit of this project was to make progress on the classification of group von Neumann algebras. Connes’ rigidity conjecture formulated in the early 1980s predicts that ICC property (T) groups are W*-superrigid, in the sense that they can be entirely reconstructed from their von Neumann algebras. One of the main outcomes obtained by the PI and his collaborators as part of this project is the construction of the first class of ICC property (T) groups which are W*-superrigid.  This result is achieved by showing that any ICC hyperbolic group with property (T) admits natural quotients, obtained via methods from geometric group theory, which are W*-superrigid. A crucial fact is that these quotient groups admit a wreath-like product structure. This structure is combined with methods from Popa’s deformation/rigidity theory to prove superrigidity. In addition to being W*-superrigid, wreath-like product groups have several other remarkable rigidity properties. For instance, the PI and his collaborators used wreath-like product groups to show that separable II_1 factors with property (T) are universal: any separable II_1 factor embeds into one with property (T). In 1980, Connes proved that any von Neumann algebra arising from an ICC property (T) group has countable outer automorphism group. Another main outcome of this project is a converse to this result: by using again wreath-like product groups, the PI and his collaborators proved that every countable group can be realized as the outer automorphism group of an ICC group with property (T).  As these results indicate, wreath-like product groups are very versatile objects. It is expected that their investigation will lead to future rigidity phenomena for groups and their von Neumann algebras.

As part of the broader impacts of this project, the PI was heavily involved in the training graduate students and mentoring postdocs, and the organization of workshops. During this award, the PI mentored four graduate students and two postdocs. The PI and his co-PIs organized a series of workshops at the interface of operator algebras, group theory and ergodic theory. These workshops stimulated collaboration between researchers in these areas. They also contributed to the professional development of graduate students and postdocs by exposing them to some of the latest developments in topics related to the project. The PI and his co-PIs were also involved in a student exchange program which allowed graduate students from one of the participant institutions (University of Iowa, Vanderbilt University, UCSD) to visit another university. This program benefitted the training of graduate students by allowing them to interact with and learn from researchers with different expertise.
